title: 111_hr6081
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Reauthorization Act of 2010" and includes amendments to the Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Act of 2005. The Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Reauthorization Act of 2010 amends the Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Act of 2005 by adjusting the cord blood inventory goals and provisions for first-degree relatives. The Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Reauthorization Act of 2010 amends the Stem Cell Therapeutic and Research Act of 2005 by adjusting cord blood inventory goals and provisions for first-degree relatives. It includes provisions for increasing cord blood unit collections, demonstrating progress towards self-sufficiency, and extending the period for recipient eligibility. The contract recipient must cease receiving Federal funds 5 years after the contract is signed, with exceptions outlined in paragraphs (2) and (3). Amendments include adjustments to cord blood inventory goals and provisions for first-degree relatives. The contract recipient must meet the requirements under subsection (d) to receive an application for a contract under this section. The inventory goal described in subsection (a) has not yet been met. The contract recipient must meet requirements to receive an application for a contract under this section. A qualified cord blood bank may be eligible for a 5-year extension if it demonstrates superior ability to meet requirements and achieve contract goals. The qualified cord blood bank must demonstrate ongoing progress towards achieving self-sufficiency in cord blood unit collection and banking operations to receive a contract extension. The Public Health Service Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the Secretary to carry out a program with specified amounts for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. Additionally, the Secretary is required to submit reports through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration. The Health Resources and Services Administration must provide an annual report to Congress on activities under this section related to cord blood. Subsection (d) specifies the Program's responsibilities regarding cord blood. The Health Resources and Services Administration must provide an annual report to Congress on activities related to cord blood, including supporting studies and projects to increase cord blood unit donation and collection from a genetically diverse population. This includes focusing on remote collection of cord blood units. The Health Resources and Services Administration must provide an annual report to Congress on activities related to cord blood, including supporting studies and projects to increase cord blood unit donation and collection from a genetically diverse population. This involves exploring novel approaches or incentives to encourage innovative technological advances for collecting cord blood units. The Health Resources and Services Administration must report annually to Congress on efforts to increase collection of high-quality cord blood units, setting annual goals and replicating projects nationwide. The Health Resources and Services Administration must report annually to Congress on efforts to expand remote collection of high-quality cord blood units nationwide, if necessary submitting a plan to the relevant committees. In addition to the annual report required under section 379(a)(6) of the Public Health Service Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must establish a system of strict confidentiality to protect patient and donor identity and privacy in accordance with Federal and State law. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Advisory Council, must submit an interim report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will detail methods for distributing Federal funds to cord blood banks, how banks contract with collection sites, and recommendations for improving fund distribution to encourage efficient collection of high-quality cord blood units. The Advisory Council will submit recommendations to the Secretary regarding remote collection of cord blood units and collection from routine deliveries without monitoring of delivery rooms in approved hospitals. Authorization of appropriations under the Public Health Service Act will be amended. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on increasing cord blood unit donation and collection for the National Cord Blood Inventory within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on challenges and barriers to expanding cord blood unit collection sites for the National Cord Blood Inventory. The report will address challenges and barriers in expanding cord blood unit collection sites for the National Cord Blood Inventory, including regulatory requirements, technological advances for remote collection, provider education, and the number and characteristics of collection sites needed to meet inventory needs. The curr_chunk discusses best practices for establishing partnerships with medical facilities for cord blood unit collection, incentives for hospitals to become collection sites, and recommendations to lower costs for cord blood banks and collection sites. The curr_chunk provides recommendations for improving the efficiency of cord blood unit collection, including lowering costs and maintaining quality. It also includes suggestions for distributing funds to cord blood banks to encourage the collection of high-quality and diverse units. The term "remote collection" is defined in the Act. The curr_chunk refers to the definition of "remote collection" as specified in the Public Health Service Act.
